2026-02-15.central_question: Should rural communities invest in self-hosted, locally controlled technology infrastructure, or are they better served relying on centralized cloud services?
2026-02-15.riley_position: Rural communities should build local technology infrastructure because costs have dropped dramatically, it provides genuine resilience against corporate failures, and communities can pool resources regionally to share expertise and costs.
riley_key_evidence: Town of Olds, Alberta delivers gigabit service for $60/month via municipal fiber cooperative O-Net
Kuhkenah Network (K-Net) maintained connectivity during 2022 Rogers outage serving First Nations communities for 30+ years
2026-02-15.casey_position: Self-hosted infrastructure is impractical for small rural communities due to high hidden costs, expertise requirements, and maintenance burdens that advocates consistently undercount.
casey_key_evidence: Olds O-Net required $40+ million investment ($4,400 per resident) with ongoing debt servicing
Qualified Linux systems administrator costs $65-85k annually - unsustainable for small communities
Rogers 2022 outage affecting 12 million people shows even billion-dollar companies with thousands of engineers fail catastrophically
2026-02-15.resolution: They reached partial agreement that building technical literacy and piloting low-risk local services is reasonable, while disagreeing on whether this would lead to widespread community infrastructure adoption or better-negotiated corporate contracts.
topics_covered: Cost analysis of local vs. corporate infrastructure
Technical expertise and volunteer sustainability
Regional cooperation models and resource pooling
Resilience comparison between centralized and distributed systems
Rural cooperative movement parallels and lessons

2026-02-16.central_question: Are digital tools and platforms genuinely empowering rural communities to tell their stories effectively, or are they creating new barriers and dependencies while promising false solutions?
2026-02-16.riley_position: Digital storytelling tools are becoming more accessible and effective for rural communities, with decreasing costs, improving infrastructure, and better governance frameworks enabling genuine cultural preservation and economic opportunities.
riley_key_evidence: First Nations Technology Council documented 47 community-led digital heritage projects across BC, with 31 in communities under 5,000 people
UBC's Oral History project provides turnkey recording kits for under $2,000 per community and has partnered with 23 communities since 2023
Starlink coverage now reaches 94% of rural BC with speeds of 50-200 Mbps, sufficient for collaborative editing and live streaming
2026-02-16.casey_position: Digital platforms create surveillance risks, dependency on corporate infrastructure, and technical barriers that exclude the most culturally knowledgeable community members while requiring unsustainable volunteer labor and funding.
casey_key_evidence: Over 60% of Arctic cultural digitization projects from 2010-2020 had no data repatriation plan when funding expired
29% of rural Canadians over 65 don't use the internet at all, with another 22% describing themselves as 'not confident' online
Meta's automated systems have repeatedly flagged Indigenous ceremony videos and traditional hunting practices as policy violations
2026-02-16.resolution: Both agreed that structural solutions like regional shared services and better funding models are needed, with Riley acknowledging infrastructure gaps while Casey conceded that governance frameworks are improving - they agreed to disagree on whether current progress outweighs the barriers.
topics_covered: Digital infrastructure and connectivity challenges in rural areas
Cultural preservation vs. platform surveillance and content moderation
Economic sustainability and monetization for rural digital creators
Intergenerational participation gaps in digital literacy
Community ownership and control of digital cultural assets

2026-02-17.central_question: Whether increasing technology dependence in resource industries like ranching, forestry, and mining will ultimately benefit or harm rural working communities in the Cariboo region.
2026-02-17.riley_position: Technology integration amplifies human expertise and creates economic opportunities through improved efficiency, grid upgrades, and diversification. The trajectory is toward more accessible, reliable systems that complement rather than replace traditional knowledge.
riley_key_evidence: Lithium iron phosphate batteries offer better cycle life than older systems
Data centers can justify utility upgrades that benefit entire rural regions
Modern systems use standardized protocols like CAN bus and Modbus for easier repair
2026-02-17.casey_position: Technology dependence creates new vulnerabilities and external dependencies that erode local self-sufficiency and resilience. The benefits concentrate elsewhere while risks and costs remain local.
casey_key_evidence: Fifteen failed Battle Born batteries showed manufacturing defects in critical battery management systems
Diesel generator repairs use local mechanics and knowledge while electronics require specialized distant technicians
Data centers can outbid resource industries for electricity, driving up power costs
2026-02-17.resolution: They agreed on key evaluation criteria: systems should increase self-sufficiency, be maintainable locally, and complement existing knowledge. Riley remained optimistic about technology's trajectory while Casey advocated planning for risks over hoping for benefits.
topics_covered: Battery reliability and maintenance infrastructure gaps
Competition between data centers and resource industries for electricity
Local technical capacity and repair capabilities
Economic diversification versus traditional industry stability
Technology as amplification versus replacement of human expertise

2026-02-18.central_question: Can AI-driven infrastructure management systems enhance rural governance while maintaining democratic accountability and community-centered decision-making?
2026-02-18.riley_position: AI infrastructure systems can transform rural governance by providing predictive maintenance, cost savings, and better resource allocation through regional cooperation models. These tools augment rather than replace human judgment and can actually increase transparency in decision-making.
riley_key_evidence: Kamloops area smart traffic systems improved rural traffic prediction after three years of local data
City of Medicine Hat saw 30% reduction in emergency road repairs with predictive systems
Thompson-Nicola Regional District exploring shared technology services model
2026-02-18.casey_position: AI systems risk creating accountability gaps and excluding communities lacking digital literacy or resources. Democratic legitimacy requires citizen understanding of decision-making processes, which sophisticated algorithms may undermine.
casey_key_evidence: Williams Lake council spent 40 minutes debating simple zoning application, showing complexity challenges
Provincial integrated service delivery platforms failed in half of rural municipalities five years ago
Digital divide exists where half the population gets news from radio and municipal websites unchanged since 2018
2026-02-18.resolution: Both agreed that technology can enhance governance if democratic accountability is built in from the start, with Casey accepting regional cooperation could work if citizens understand decision-making processes, and Riley acknowledging that human elements of democracy must be preserved.
topics_covered: Predictive maintenance vs. reactive infrastructure management
Regional cooperation and shared technology services
Democratic accountability and citizen understanding of AI decisions
Digital divide in rural civic engagement
Cost-benefit analysis of municipal AI adoption

2026-02-19.central_question: Can Indigenous communities use technology to shift power relationships and control innovation processes, or are they being forced to innovate around systemic problems while facing extractive timelines?
2026-02-19.riley_position: Indigenous communities can lead innovation by controlling technology development from the start, using tools like blockchain, digital governance platforms, and environmental monitoring to strengthen self-determination and shift power dynamics.
riley_key_evidence: Coast Salish artists using traditional and digital media for visual storytelling systems
Himalayan communities using traditional ice harvesting with modern materials for glacier grafting
Indigenous communities building blockchain registries and peer-to-peer networks for knowledge preservation
2026-02-19.casey_position: While Indigenous-led innovation has potential, communities face structural power imbalances with government and industry operating on faster timelines, forcing reactive responses rather than genuine control over development.
casey_key_evidence: BC's accelerated critical minerals extraction without meaningful Indigenous consent
Premier Eby's comments about reconciliation legislation being 'in the way' of economic development
Communities being asked to make decisions about projects with decades-long implications under rushed consultation processes
2026-02-19.resolution: Both agreed that Indigenous technological sovereignty should be a prerequisite for resource development, with funding from industry, and concluded by asking listeners what Indigenous-led innovation would look like specifically in Cariboo communities.
topics_covered: Digital preservation and cultural knowledge documentation
Critical minerals extraction vs Indigenous consent processes
Indigenous-controlled technology infrastructure requirements
Scale mismatches between community governance and global commodity timelines
Technology as a tool for shifting power relationships rather than just responding to them

2026-02-20.central_question: Is advancing technology genuinely improving backcountry safety accessibility for rural communities, or is it creating new barriers and false confidence?
2026-02-20.riley_position: Technology is democratizing backcountry safety through more affordable devices, better educational tools, and expanding satellite connectivity that makes comprehensive safety equipment accessible to more people.
riley_key_evidence: Amazfit T-Rex Ultra 2 offers premium GPS features at half the cost of Garmin devices
Apple's Emergency SOS via satellite is built into mainstream phones without per-message fees
Starlink and cellular carriers are expanding rural connectivity infrastructure
2026-02-20.casey_position: Technology creates equity barriers and false confidence while failing to address fundamental challenges like training access, connectivity gaps, and the need for hands-on backcountry skills.
casey_key_evidence: Avalanche Canada's app was initially built for users who already understood technical terminology
Williams Lake's avalanche safety program disappeared after two seasons when the coordinator left
Satellite communicators still cost hundreds of dollars plus monthly fees, creating income-based safety tiers
2026-02-20.resolution: They converged on community-based solutions that integrate technology thoughtfully, agreeing that local partnerships and rural-specific programs offer more promise than waiting for generic tech solutions.
topics_covered: Technology equity and affordability barriers
Rural connectivity and infrastructure challenges
Training program sustainability and access
Technology literacy versus traditional backcountry skills
Community-based implementation strategies
